VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The CAP
required was the outcome of the Renewal Inspection for 2024 and involved
addressing 4 rule violations. The violations involved CCI Rule 400.4113 1.f.ii, CCI
Rule 400.4113 1.i, CCI Rule 400.4113 1.j, CCI Rule 400.4114 1. The facility
updated policies/procedures as required, updated the electronic HR record
keeping system as requested, and informed the identified administration staff of
the changes. This CAP was reviewed quarterly and successfully completed on
3/27/25.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator identified that a CAP prior to this reporting period was
successfully completed as was the CAP for the renewal inspection last year. She
supports this success on the fact that there were no repeat violations found during
this interim inspection. Because of a budget increase the program has been able to
hire more staff thus ensuring the appropriate level of supervision is being provided
through the overnight hours. It is also documented the onboarding process for new
employees now includes “in-person bed-check training”. They are providing more
oversite for new employees as part of the on-boarding process. The Chief
Administrator notes there is a change in stays at the shelter with more youth seeing
alternative places to stay quickly so stays at the shelter are shorter in duration. She
notes with the higher level of oversite; there is a higher level of staff turnover since
negative issues with staff are identified quicker. Thus, the staff who stay are more
qualified to provide the level of care required.
3

Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff were interviewed and all were part of the administration team. No direct care
staff were present because currently the program has no youth. Staff reported they
are in the transition phase of putting all records into a new electronic system. They
reported some struggles with the new system but understand as they use the
program more, it will help with record keeping. They reported with no youth in the
program; they are able to clean the building and make any changes to the physical
structure such as painting and rearranging items.
No youth are currently in the program and the last youth left about a week ago.
Description of Agency Walk Through
This is a two-story facility of which youth only use the first floor. The facility is
another structure but well maintained and clean. All systems (heating, plumbing,
electrical) are in working order. Fire extinguishers are up to date, emergency drills
are in compliance with rules, and bed check logs are being completed
appropriately. Medication, cleaning supplies, and all chemical items are locked in
compliance with rules. Required postings were observed and youth files were
secured.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
